Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mechanisms of Diffusion of State/Non-State Legal Agreements

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the factors contributing to the successful spread of laws from one country to another. Unlike other studies of diffusion, the project focuses on a law that originated in the developing world and has spread both to other developing countries and has begun to penetrate the developed world, The production sharing contract (a form of law governing ownership of resources) now challenges the concession and state ownership systems as the dominant model of ownership of certain natural resources. The project proposes that the success of the production sharing contract is attributable in large part to processes of learning and emulation, rather than coercion or competition, with domestic politics playing a crucial role in determining which countries are perceived as role models. The project will test this hypothesis by combining quantitative analysis of an original data set of global petroleum laws from 1960 to 2010 with qualitative analysis of interviews with petroleum industry experts and archival materials from industry publications and U.S. government documents.

Apart from advancing knowledge about legislation in the petroleum industry through its eventual dissemination at conferences and through publication, the project promises to improve understanding about how to successfully promote legal innovations across developing countries as well as to recognize the contributions of developing countries as developers and promoters of new laws. It also will contribute to future research with the release of its original data set.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nicole Weygandt conducted research for her dissertation “The Diffusion of Production Sharing Contracts in the Petroleum Industry” with the support of an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. The research aims to improve understanding of the factors driving the spread of policies and laws across national borders. Building on recent work in law and political science, Ms. Weygandt proposes that the mechanisms of diffusion – coercion, competition, emulation, and learning – are likely to operate differently in interactions strictly between developing or “periphery” countries than in more commonly studied center-periphery cases. She tests this argument by examining petroleum laws, focusing on the case of the production sharing agreement, a petroleum regime developed in Indonesia in the 1960s. Specifically, she hypothesizes that learning and emulation are likely to be more influential than coercion and competition in this case, and that domestic politics plays an important role in determining which countries are viewed as role models. These propositions are tested using a multi-method research design.

With the support of the NSF DDRIG, Ms. Weygandt performed archival research at the National Archives in College Park, MD, where she reviewed petroleum-related State Department documents, focusing on Indonesia’s oil negotiations and the OPEC nationalizations. She is drawing on electronic archives from industry trade journals to supplement this government perspective. The grant also supported travel to Houston, New York, Boston, and Washington, DC to interview industry experts from the private sector, non-governmental organizations, intergovernmental organizations, and academia about petroleum fiscal systems and the factors influencing governments’ choices among those systems. She is compiling a global database of oil laws that lays out the fiscal systems used worldwide from 1960 to 2014, and is using this data to perform quantitative analysis to assess the influence of the four mechanisms of diffusion.

Upon completion of the dissertation, Ms. Weygandt will disseminate the results in academic, industry, and policy circles, influencing thinking about diffusion as well as improving understanding of the process by which countries choose among oil laws. She will also make the database available to other researchers. With the consent of interview participants, she also intends to make transcripts of the interviews available through a qualitative data archive. By sharing data in this way, the project advances research credibility and enables future research on energy and legal topics for a range of disciplines. By enabling these activities, the grant has contributed to graduate training, benefits scholars through access to new theoretical insights and data, and also advances work with implications for policy-makers interested in increasing the effectiveness of efforts to spread innovations across borders.
